entry.title: The Elevator Code on Your Wrist
entry.content:
At the Flatiron School, we have been covering a lot of ground - from Javascript to JQuery, Rake to Rails. I can’t remember a time when I have been exposed to material of this breadth, depth, and usefulness. But I’m having a particularly hard time with remembering the five digit elevator code to get access to the second floor.

I was fine the first time, even the second round, which had some sequential numbers in it. But my brain seems to be too full to commit the latest five digit code to memory.

There are simple analog solutions, like writting the code on my hand or on a piece of paper. But why do that when it seemed like the perfect excuse to toy around with the Pebble Software Developer Kit.

Having spent a whopping five days learning Javascript, I felt expert enough to dive into PebbleJS, a Javascript based watch application tool (still in Beta) to see if I could code a solution to my Elevator Code conundrum.

I had a lot of fancy ideas about triggering a location or time-based reminder. Or even creating a JSON endpoint that could be updated and read remotely. But we are in project mode and I have a tech talk to prepare for next week. So I have put the fancy features in the icebox and opted for a six-line solution. Essentially, I am using Pebble’s UI library, creating a Card object and displaying it on the screen.

Now, of course, that’s not the real code, so don’t get any ideas about coming to Flatiron with it. The only way to get into the school is to apply.

Pebble raised over $10 million dollars in May of 2012 with their first Kickstarter campaign making the the largest and most successful campaign of the time. They did it again with their new watch, which raised $20,338,986 with over 74,000 backers in March of this year. The Pebble community is active and its core users are dedicated.

Also, the Pebble Developer tools are very easy to use. CloudPebble is an online console and development environment that also handles deploying to your watch - including an online watch emulator. And they have spent a lot of time making the API easy to use with lots of sample code.. For example, making an ajax call is fairly straightforward.

We don’t know how many Apple Watches have been sold, but its clear that the wearable market - whether its big or small - is not just a fad. As a programmers, its good to think of the small screen on the wrist as an extension of any application. Certainly, PebbleJS is a good place for anyone with Javascript experience to get started.

If your project team has time, you might want to think about creating a JSON endpoint to open up your data to the world of wearables.

<p>layout: post<br />
title: “The Elevator Code on Your Wrist”<br />
date: 2015-05-25 19:23:06 -0400<br />
comments: true<br />
categories: </p>
<hr />
<p><img class="<a" src="href="http://dadhoc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/pebble_elevator.jpg">http://dadhoc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/pebble_elevator.jpg</a>” width=”500”></p>
<p>At the Flatiron School, we have been covering a lot of ground - from Javascript to JQuery, Rake to Rails. I can’t remember a time when I have been exposed to material of this breadth, depth, and usefulness. But I’m having a particularly hard time with remembering the five digit elevator code to get access to the second floor. </p>
<p>I was fine the first time, even the second round, which had some sequential numbers in it. But my brain seems to be too full to commit the latest five digit code to memory. </p>
<p>There are simple analog solutions, like writting the code on my hand or on a piece of paper. But why do that when it seemed like the perfect excuse to toy around with the Pebble Software Developer Kit. </p>
<p>Having spent a whopping five days learning Javascript, I felt expert enough to dive into <a href="http://developer.getpebble.com/docs/pebblejs/">PebbleJS</a>, a Javascript based watch application tool (still in Beta) to see if I could code a solution to my Elevator Code conundrum. </p>
<p>I had a lot of fancy ideas about triggering a location or time-based reminder. Or even creating a JSON endpoint that could be updated and read remotely. But we are in project mode and I have a tech talk to prepare for next week. So I have put the fancy features in the icebox and opted for a six-line solution. Essentially, I am using Pebble’s UI library, creating a <code>Card</code> object and displaying it on the screen. </p>
<p><pre><code class="javascript">var UI = require('ui');

// Create a Card with title and subtitle
var card = new UI.Card({
  title:"Elevator Code",
  subtitle:'26452'
});

// Display the Card
card.show();
</code></pre><br />
Now, of course, that’s not the real code, so don’t get any ideas about coming to Flatiron with it. The only way to get into the school is to apply. </p>
<p><img class="<a" src="href="http://dadhoc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Screen-Shot-2015-05-26-at-7.16.12-AM.png">http://dadhoc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Screen-Shot-2015-05-26-at-7.16.12-AM.png</a>”></p>
<p>Pebble raised over $10 million dollars in May of 2012 with their first Kickstarter campaign making the the largest and most successful campaign of the time. They did it again with their new watch, which raised $20,338,986 with over 74,000 backers in March of this year. The Pebble community is active and its core users are dedicated.  </p>
<p>Also, the Pebble Developer tools are very easy to use. CloudPebble is an online console and development environment that also handles deploying to your watch - including an online watch emulator. And they have spent a lot of time making the API easy to use with lots of sample code.. For example, making an ajax call is fairly straightforward. </p>
<p><pre><code class="javascript">// Make the request
ajax(
  {
    url: URL,
    type: 'json'
  },
  function(data) {
    // Success!
    console.log('Successfully fetched weather data!');
  },
  function(error) {
    // Failure!
    console.log('Failed fetching weather data: ' + error);
  }
);
</code></pre><br />
We don’t know how many Apple Watches have been sold, but its clear that the wearable market - whether its big or small - is not just a fad. As a programmers, its good to think of the small screen on the wrist as an extension of any application. Certainly, PebbleJS is a good place for anyone with Javascript experience to get started. </p>
<p>If your project team has time, you might want to think about creating a JSON endpoint to open up your data to the world of wearables. </p></article></body></html>

entry.title: TimeCoder - a Handy Sublime Text 3 Plugin
entry.content:
One of the cool things about the Flatiron School is that every lecture is recorded. That way, it is easy to go back over a topic that might still be fuzzy - or that you might want to review after gaining more perspective. But these lectures can be two hours long and cover a lot of ground. It can be hard to get right to a specific area or topic.

Our instructor, Steven Nunez has us all clap at the beginning of a lecture, for his own audio sync (and to wake us up). But it also marks the beginning of his video (or close to it). I thought my review sessions could be a lot more effecient if I had a timecode to match my notes. I write in Sublime and it turns out that it has a robust API and its pretty straightforward to get started with Sublime Text Plugin development. Forget about the fact that their language is based in Python and I have been spending the last 6+ weeks learning Ruby.

In the words of a famous programmer, “We’re programmers, damnit!” So I went for it.

I’ll go over the steps I took to create TimeCoder, my first Sublime Text 3 Plugin. But for a comprehensive tutorial, I recommend this one and this one as good starting points. You’ll also want to take a good look at the Sublime Text API Reference. You, too, can extend the functionality of your text editor with ease. Before I do that, here’s a short video showing the functionality of TimeCoder.

Sublime Makes it really easy to create a plug in. You go to Tools->New Plugin… and you get a new document with some python code to get you started.

On a mac, you store this file in a new folder in this directory. There you will put your .py file as well as your .sublime-keymap and sublime-menu files. More on those in a second.

Once its there, you call it by typing the following:

But obviously, you and your users will want a different way of calling the command. Later, we’ll add key bindings to these commands.

I created two commands. One that starts the timer and sets a note to the top of the document with the start time. And a second one that marks the timer. Here’s all the code needed for the plug in! Just 29 lines of code and I have saved myself a lot of time and grief looking for some particular gem of wisdom.

So, how to get those key bindins to work. Create a file called Default (OSX).sublime-keymap. There are other ones for Windows as well as Linux, but I made with with my Flatiron cohort in mind and we are all on Macs.

So, the next time Steven mentions something amazing that you only have a 69% understanding. Mark the time, watch that part of the video and bump it up to 75% or even 80%! Why not aim big!

The GIT repository is here. Feel free to download and use. Just put this into a folder in that /Packages directory listed above. And feel free to tinker around with it. Let me know how it goes!

Thanks to Parker Lawrence for helping me debug the timer!

entry.title: The Immersive Web
entry.content:
When Facebook bought Oculus Rift for $2 Billion just over a year ago, it marked the beginning of a new era in Virtual Reality. While there have been many attempts at virtual reality systems, the Oculus is the first one that promises to bring a truly immersive virtual reality experience to consumers. Even though Oculus has yet to released a consumer product, its second generation development kit sold over 100,000 units.

The first wave of enthusiasm around VR, as with many early tech adopters, are gamers. Playing Call of Duty or Minecraft in a 360 virtual environment will certainly hold an appeal to the largest and most motivated segment of users. Guys like this:

But in a Facebook post to announce his company’s purchase of the VR startup, Mark Zuckerberg said:

After games, we’re going to make Oculus a platform for many other experiences. Imagine enjoying a court side seat at a game, studying in a classroom of students and teachers all over the world or consulting with a doctor face-to-face – just by putting on goggles in your home. This is really a new communication platform. By feeling truly present, you can share unbounded spaces and experiences with the people in your life. Imagine sharing not just moments with your friends online, but entire experiences and adventures.

What will it be like to navigate the web in a 360 immersive environment? Will our kids wonder how we all dealt with these tiny 15” screens as they consume their content in 360 degrees?

360 content creation won’t hit the mainstream until devices like the Oculus are widely (and inexpensively) available. And we are a ways from that. Cutting edge content creators are already making incredible experiences enabled by the Oculus Rift.

You can fly like a bird with Birdly.

You can also experience terror like no film can provide.

One format that we will all hear more about as VR grows is 360 video. Without spending a lot of time or money, its really hard to put together a 360 video. But imagine if you can drop a 360 camera in the middle of a birthday party (or concert or wedding), then other people can experience that event by being surrounded by it. I would suspect that one of first widely adopted non-gaming VR use will be in shooting and sharing 360 video.

In fact, YouTube started to support 360 video as of March of this year. The selections are slim for now, but as the camera as well as software technology improves, 360 video will no be a specialized niche, but just another way to share our stories.

In addition to 360 video we will see 3D worlds, location tours, product demos. Many of them will be powered by well documented and distributed frameworks and libraries such as three.js and WebGL, which already support Oculus Rift output.

What does this mean to web developers? Not much for the near and mid-term, but it is worth thinking about how we will migrate our 2D content into a 3D world. And how this new immersive medium will change the way we tell stories, present information, and navigate through 360 degrees of content.

entry.title: Hello_Rake
entry.content:
I recently got my first taste of Rake, a powerful build language developed by Jim Weirich, a famous developer and contributor to the Ruby language. In addition to creating Rake, he was part of a team of developers who built RubyGems in 2003.

Rake tops the list as the most downloaded gem of all time with current download numbers within striking distance of 70 million. It is a ubiquitous file management tool. Since I am new to Ruby and even newer to Rake, I thought it would be useful to provide a quick introduction to Rake.

My first encounter with Rake was in my installation of this Octopress blog. I had no idea that I was also in such esteemed company as Martin Fowler, who builds his website with Rake and wrote an extensive blog post about why he likes it. It’s worth checking out.

For starters Rake is a DSL. No, we aren’t talking about an old-fashioned Internet connection. A DSL is a Domain Specific Language, which is essentially a computer language that’s targeted to a specific purpose. CSS, regular expressions, and SQL are three other examples of DSLs that I have encountered so far.

Dependencies

One of the most useful aspects of using Rake is that it can track and group your programs dependencies. Every program has files that it requires to run and a Rake file is the perfect way of managing all of the files that make up your environment.

Namespaces

For example, you can group different dependencies based on if you are working in a development or production environment. You aren’t going to need your rspec testing files in a production environment or for your deployed web application. In theory, by the time its live, you have already tested things out.

Tasks

This is where Rake gets and gives instructions about how to run your program. You can describe or desc your tasks as well as give them prerequisites detailing other tasks to run before your task.

Arguments

A Rake task can also take arguments. I won’t go over the syntax here, but will point you to this comprehensive answer on Stack Overflow.

Scheduling your scripts

As you get more comfortable creating and running your tasks with Rake, you might find that there are some you want to do outside of the regular testing cycle. Perhaps you want to test an email server in the middle of the night. Or schedule a monthly report. With Rake, you can do that!

cron is a Unix utility for scheduling and executing commands. You can access it from the command line by typing crontab -e called cron to use Rake to schedule your tasks. You might have a program that you want to test in the middle of the night (while you are sleeping). You can use rake to test it.

You can read more about using cron to schedule command line here.

Rake is at the heart of a programmer’s workflow. I will leave you with more thoughtful works from Martin Fowler:

Scripts are a natural for building stuff in many ways, and rake adds just enough features to provide a really good build system on top of a fine language. We also have the advantage that ruby is an open source language that runs on all the platforms that I need.

As my programs get more and more complex in terms of environment, function, testing, and dependencies, I’m looking forward to delving even deeper into its syntax and uses.

You might have noticed that the title of this post is Hello_Rake… Well, that underscore wasn’t my way of being “programmery”. Octopress didn’t like having Rake in the title of the post. I’m sure there was a way around that by escaping the characters properly, but I figured that’s something for another day.

Happy Raking.

entry.title: Coding Cliches
entry.content:
Rewriting Cliches into Ruby

One of the most striking things about Ruby is its expressiveness. A Ruby block of programming oftens reads with the logic and fluidity of spoken language. Which makes sense, because it was designed with the programmer in mind.

As I learned new commands, I kept associating them with real-world scenarios like if hungry then eat else work end. So, I decided to translate some well-known cliches into theoretically working Ruby.

Since I’m a beginner, some of the syntax and operations might be off, but please feel free to suggest any changes/refactoring! Have a fun cliche that might look cool in Ruby? Please add it into the comments!

Thanks to my teammate Cassidy Robertson for finding and sending me a great list of cliches.
